header.title: The Grandmother of Time: A Woman's Book of Celebrations, Spells, and Sacred Objects for Every Month of the Year
header.category: Western Esotericism, Witchcraft, Dianic Wicca, Feminist Spirituality, Goddess Worship

central_thesis: The core thesis posits that ancient European goddess-centered traditions and holidays offer a vital spiritual and operative path for contemporary individuals, particularly women, to achieve self-healing, personal growth, and collective action. By reconnecting with these ancestral practices, practitioners can reclaim inherent spiritual power, live more joyously, and actively shape a better world, distinct from or in critical dialogue with patriarchal religious narratives. The book emphasizes the cyclical nature of time and life, guided by the Great Mother in her various aspects.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction: An Invitation from Anna Perenna, the Grandmother of Time
structure_content.summary: Introduces Anna Perenna as the eternal Goddess of Time, guide for the year, and an ancient deity worshipped for millennia. Emphasizes her role as the 'beginning and the end, the alpha and omega,' guiding individuals to internalize the sacred calendar. Highlights the book's focus on lost European traditions before Christianization, but also includes global traditions to show unity of spirit. It sets the stage for a journey 'around the brilliant sun' with Anna as the captain, offering messages and spells for benefit.

structure_content.chapter_title: January - The Goddess Speaks: Anna Perenna
structure_content.summary: Focuses on Anna Perenna as the goddess of the coming year, emphasizing hope, new beginnings, and a cyclical calendar (Spiral Dance) that includes eight major holidays. January's aspects include the Cold Moon, inception of the new year, planting of spring wheat, self-perpetuation, healing for joints/skin, and dedication of new goals. Practical elements include a 'Birthday Celebration' ritual (shifting from blowing out candles to lighting them sequentially for years lived), a 'Spell for Healthy Sleep' using Herba euphrasia, a 'Spell to Stop Smoking' with gentian powder and a smoking mixture, a 'General Purification Spell' for cleansing space and self, and a 'Meditation to Dispel Fear'.

structure_content.chapter_title: February - The Goddess Speaks: Hagia Sophia
structure_content.summary: Hagia Sophia (divine wisdom) heralds an initiation, a surging spiritual strength, and a new dawn for women's spiritual power. February's aspects include the Wild Moon (red and cleansing), Quickening of life, Candlemas Sabbat (initiations), purification, growth, and healing. Spells include a 'Spell to Win a Loved One' using two personalized candles and a rose thorn for inscription, a 'Powerful Money Spell' involving a green cloth doll stuffed with rowan/eucalyptus/rose petals/clover and anointed, a 'Spell to Purify Your Home & Possessions' using sage incense, and a 'Spell for Victory' employing three purple candles for the Three Fates and a working candle of specific color based on the goal.

Kore, the Divine Maiden, represents resurrection, new growth, and prolific energy. March's aspects include the Storm Moon, Spring Equinox, blessing of fields and animals, dedication of newborn babies, and personal growth. The chapter introduces 'Dedication of a New Baby' rituals involving a public and a secret name, offerings, and invocations of the four elements. A 'Money Spell' is detailed, using green and orange candles, specific intentions, and disposal of remnants in water. Also discussed are 'Native American Puberty Rite for Girls' and 'Celebration of a Modern Young Woman's First Blood,' emphasizing the importance of ritualizing female milestones.

Aphrodite embodies raw, unbridled sexuality, love, death, and transformation. April's aspects include the Seed Moon, budding trees, nesting birds, May Eve, and appropriate spells for passion and devotions to the dead. The chapter covers the 'Hudough Dance' (a Native American custom for sexual freedom), a 'Blessing on Your Genitals' meditation with musk incense, a 'Blessing on Lovers' ritual using myrtle branches under a full moon, 'Devotion for the Dead' involving grave visits and candles, and the 'Haloa' festival (a Greek women-only event for free speech and sexual expression).

Artemis, the Lady of the Beasts and protector of young life, emphasizes wildness, freedom, and self-defense. May's aspects include the Hare Moon, flowers coming forth, chastity, healing (fevers/infections), and spells for finding new jobs/homes, settling disagreements, physical fitness, and divination. Practical applications include 'Artemis & The Children' (story and blessing), 'Spell for May: Blessing on the Children' (flower crowns, chalk crescent moon mark), 'Arretophoria: Nymph Festival' (house blessing by young girls with incense and bells), a 'Spell to Find a Home' using a drawn map and a brown candle, and spells for 'Productive Studying' and 'Finding a (Nonspecific) Job' with yellow/purple candles and divination.

Hera represents personal power, leadership, order, and protection of women and new citizens. June's aspects include the Mead Moon, strong sun, Midsummer Night (a three-day festival for bonding, loyalty, and triumphant fulfillment), and spells for protection and hexes. Rituals include 'Chanting for Personal Power' (with offerings to Juno/Hera), a 'Spell to Magically Defeat a Law' (using vinegar, honey, brandy, and burning paper links of unjust laws), and a 'Spell to Stop Harassment at Home, Work, or School' (using a black candle, urine, and black pepper for the harasser).

Athena embodies strength, wisdom, talent, and leadership for women, specifically in resolving conflicts without violence. July's aspects include the Harvest Moon, increase, overthrow of the old order, prevention/protection, and spells for blessings on fields, love, health, and money. Spells include a 'Voodoo Spell for Wealth' (green cloth doll with hair, bay leaves, clover, cinnamon oil, gold dust), a 'Self-Blessing for Health, Wealth, Love, or Wisdom' (using powdered mountain ash leaves blown to cardinal directions), 'The Magic of Mugwort' for amorousness, 'Prayers for Peace in the Family' (with henna and floating lights), and 'A Marriage Ceremony for Those Who Feel It Is Time for Trysting' for commitment.

Ceres, the Earth Mother, emphasizes abundance, nurturing, and the responsibility of women to protect the Earth and use their power collectively. August's aspects include the Barley Moon, Lammas (festival of the new bread), and activities for concentrated wisdom and psychic development. Spells include a 'Spell to Increase Your Business' (herbs like Echinacea, augustifolia, cubeb berries, yellow dock burnt with sandalwood), a 'Spell for Health & Against Accidents' (feverfew tea or carried in a red flannel bag), a 'Spell to See Visions' (sandalwood, anise seeds, myrtle, Indian hemp burnt with frankincense/myrrh before meditating or retiring to bed), and a 'Spell to End Hatred Between Two People' (ironweed in whiskey).

structure_content.chapter_title: September - The Goddess Speaks: The Muse
structure_content.summary: The Muse inspires creativity, art, and the pursuit of higher goals, emphasizing security as an illusion and creativity as humanity's true occupation. September's aspects include the Harvest Moon, Autumn Equinox/Mabon (three-day revels with sacred mushrooms, though cautioned against), and prevention through tonics. Spells include 'Spell Thanking the Goddess for Favors Received' (acacia flowers/sap incense), 'Spell to Drive a Poltergeist from Your Premises' (bistort tea for floor wash), 'Spell to Help Angry Couples to Kiss & Make Up' (black cohosh around bed), 'Spell to Keep a Wandering Lover at Home' (yerba mate tea), and 'Skira: Creativity Festival' for creating goddess images.

Hecate is the Crone, Queen of the Crossroads, and transformer, associated with death, rebirth, and the thinning veil between worlds. October's aspects include the Blood Moon, Samhain (Halloween), summer's end, and preparation for winter. Spells include 'To Destroy an Enemy's Power to Harm' (ague root, crushed patchouli leaves, myrrh, olibanum tears, wood betony incense with invocation), 'Spell to Stop Slander & Gossip' (powdered cloves and written names burned), 'Spell to Travel in Safety' (Iceland moss in luggage), a 'Rite to Honor the Dead' (altar with photos, food, incense), and a 'Spell to Let Go' (listing resentments and burning them with black candles and incense).

structure_content.chapter_title: November - The Goddess Speaks: The Crone
structure_content.summary: The Crone represents rebirth, wisdom, and guidance into the next life. November's aspects include the Snow Moon, Feast of the Dead (November 1), seeking guidance and prophecies, and healing overindulgence. Spells include 'Spell to Improve Psychic Powers' (yellow candles, saffron tea, spine visualization, psychic herbs), and 'Stenia: The Bitching Festival' (a ritual for women to discuss negative emotions. Anciently, matrons would be visited by young women in tents, exchanging verbal insults, throwing dirt bombs, wrestling matches (short of drawing blood), resolving resentments. Acknowledging therapy groups as modern equivalent).

Lucina, the Sun Goddess, embodies rebirth, introspection, and renewal during the Winter Solstice. December's aspects include the Moon of Long Nights, Winter Solstice Sabbat (December 21), revitalizing waters, purification of body and soul. Spells include a 'Spell to Help Those in Depression' (huckleberry/sage incense, circle, invocation of Hecate), a 'Spell to Find Inner Peace' (sending forgiveness messages with lavender), and 'Winter Solstice Practices' (Yule Tree decoration, eggnog, candle burning, journal writing). Additional spells are 'Spell to Bring Fast Luck' (job's tears seeds in pillow), 'Spell to Attract a Lover' (queen's root), and 'Spell to Call on the Angelic Forces' (pipsissewa, rose/violet powder, vanilla incense with white/seven-power candles).

key_concepts.definition: The foundational deity of the system, embodying cyclical time, renewal, and the beginning/end. She serves as a guide for personal and collective transformation throughout the year's sacred calendar. Her attributes include prescience (looking backward and forward, like Janus, identified as a masculinized form of Anna), and deep connection to Earth's rhythms.

Budapest's interpretation of the Wheel of the Year, comprising eight major holidays (Samhain, Winter Solstice, Candlemas, Spring Equinox, May Eve, Summer Solstice, Lammas, Autumn Equinox). This cycle is presented as the Goddess's ancient dance, a framework for seasonal celebrations and spiritual growth.

A core philosophical stance emphasizing the divine feminine as primary, promoting women's empowerment, self-love, and challenging patriarchal norms. This tradition informs all rituals and spells in the book, advocating for women's autonomy in spiritual and societal matters. The author describes herself as a founder of the Women's Spirituality Movement and Susan B. Anthony Coven Number 1.

A karmic principle governing magical ethics. 'If you use the Goddess for frivolous, greedy reasons, it will rebound upon you threefold. If you attack the innocent, it will rebound upon you tenfold. If you stand up for yourself or others in need of help, your luck will improve threefold.' This clarification moves beyond a simplistic 'harm none' to include justified self-defense and action for justice.

Structured ceremonies designed to acknowledge and celebrate significant life transitions (birth, puberty, middle age, menopause, death). These rituals aim to provide communal validation, psychological integration, and spiritual strength, filling a void left by modern secular society. They emphasize internalizing changes and affirming one's evolving identity within a sacred context.

Practical techniques using herbs, candles, visualizations, and invocations to influence reality, manifest desires, heal, protect, and connect with divine energies. Emphasis is placed on inner strength, clear intention, and aligning with lunar phases and seasonal energies. A key principle for manifestation is the 'don't-look-back' act of release after casting.

An aspect of the Triple Goddess, representing wisdom, death, transformation, and guiding souls to rebirth. Celebrated at Samhain/Halloween and in November, she presides over the letting go of the old and the introspection required for new cycles. Middle age (56+) is celebrated as the 'age of wisdom' for women, where they embody the Crone archetype.

Various Goddesses (Kore, Aphrodite, Artemis, Hera, Athena, Ceres, The Muse, Hecate, Lucina, Isis, Inanna, Brigid, Diana, Sheila Na Gig, etc.) are presented as different manifestations or 'aspects' of the primordial Great Mother. Each monthly chapter introduces a specific Goddess aspect, offering unique wisdom, strengths, and magical associations to align with seasonal energies and personal needs, embodying aspects of life from love and fertility to wisdom and death.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a comprehensive approach to Dianic Witchcraft and Goddess Spirituality, structured around a yearly cycle of monthly themes, associated Goddess archetypes, and specific magical workings. It emphasizes direct communion with the Divine Feminine for personal and communal empowerment, healing, protection, and manifestation. The system encourages practitioners to align their lives with the natural rhythms of the Earth and lunar phases, utilizing a diverse array of ritual tools and techniques. A key element is the integration of magical practice with social and political activism, reflecting the feminist ethos of the tradition. Practitioners are guided to develop intuition, trust their inner wisdom, and actively engage in creating a 'sacred calendar' of celebrations and rites of passage to bring spiritual depth and joy into modern life.
tools: Candles (white, green, orange, purple, red, yellow, black, seven-power candles for specific magical purposes and deities)
Incense (sandalwood, sage, frankincense, myrrh, cedar, cinnamon, acacia sap, wood betony, olibanum, uva ursi, nutmeg powder, orrisroot powder for atmosphere, channeling, cleansing, and offerings)

Herbs (Herba euphrasia, hops, skullcap, chamomile, gentian powder, red clover, colt's foot, mullein, linden flowers, sweet basil, bayberry, dittany of Crete, powdered cloves, birch twigs, rowan leaves, eucalyptus, rose petals, clover, poke root, bistort, black cohosh, yerba mate, mugwort, pipsissewa, rose powder, violet powder, vanilla, huckleberry, red raspberry leaves, Iceland moss, ironweed, ague root for specific magical properties, stuffing dolls, teas, or infusions)

Ritual Objects (altar, white parchment paper, red ink, rose thorn, crystal ball, chalices, flower crowns, images/statues of goddesses, bells, sword, drums, string/thread/ribbon, red flannel bag, mortar and pestle, mirror, paper links for laws, green cloth doll, straw effigies for Carmentalia)
Natural Elements (water from rivers/lakes/sea for casting remnants or rain dance, earth for grounding, fire for burning/purification, air for invocation)
Personal Items (urine, saliva, hair, perfume/shaving lotion for anointing and sympathetic magic)
Food/Drink (apples, pears, wine, juices, seafood, barley, salt, water, sweets, red fruit, hard candies, eggnog, cakes for offerings and feasts)
rituals: Birthday Celebration (January): Lighting candles for years lived, storytelling, giving thanks.

General Purification Spell (January): Cleaning space, drafting goals, anointing a 13-day votive candle with violet oil/perfume/saliva, slapping birch twigs on body/house while chanting for purification.
Spell for Healthy Sleep (January): Drinking Herba euphrasia tea for restful sleep and prophetic dreams.

Spell to Stop Smoking (January): Gentian powder capsules, smoking red clover/colt's foot/mullein mixture, using a green image candle inscribed with name and anointed, visualizing healing light, chanting affirmations of body reclamation.
Meditation to Dispel Fear (January): Quiet meditation with white candle and sage, visualizing a safe temple, receiving protection from the Goddess, chanting affirmations.

Spell to Win a Loved One (February): Begun during waxing moon, using two personalized red candles (one for self, one for target/'my own true love'), inscribing names with a rose thorn, lighting white altar candles and sage incense, chanting invocations to the Goddess of Love, moving candles closer over three full moon nights, then casting remnants into moving water.

Powerful Money Spell (February): During waxing moon, creating a green cloth doll stuffed with rowan/eucalyptus/rose petals/clover, marking eyes/nose/mouth with red thread, decorating altar with evergreens, lighting green and orange candles, anointing doll, invoking spirits of wealth, powdering with glitter, hiding doll for nine nights, burning it after manifestation.

Spell to Purify Your Home & Possessions (February): Using sage incense to circle home/car clockwise three times while reciting protective prayers, placing incense in the door, carrying poke root/shells/rabbit's foot as a car charm.

Spell for Victory (February): During waxing moon, targeting a specific goal, using sandalwood incense and three purple candles (for Three Fates) with a working candle of appropriate color (brown for getting/holding, green for new growth, pink for love, red for fight, yellow for brainchild), inscribing goal with a rose thorn/pencil, invoking Lady Victory, chanting affirmations of territorial claim, repeating seven nights, casting remnants into living water.

Dedication of a New Baby (March): On first day of full moon, gathering celebrants around a tree, setting out special dishes (barley, salt, water), lighting white candles, guardian mother calls circle, invoking four elements (East/air/imagination, South/fire/will/passion, West/waters/love/connection, North/earth/form/laws), encircling baby with barley, salt, and water while blessing, holding baby to full moon and pronouncing name.

Money Spell (March): During new crescent moon, decorating a white table with flowers/objects of abundance, placing jewels/gold/heirlooms, four green candles for directions, one orange candle for self in center, writing desired amount on candles, lighting cinnamon/sage incense, visualizing wealth like scattered seeds, chanting for Habondia, moving candles closer for 3, 7, or 9 nights, disposing of remnants in water.

Native American Puberty Rite for Girls (March): Mother chooses three elders to instruct young woman during three days/nights in a windowless hut, covering her head, special foods/drinks. (Described as a traditional practice, not a spell for user to perform directly, but to learn from).

Celebration of a Modern Young Woman's First Blood (March): Party for friends/relatives, mother buys a red-stone ring, mother presents ring with declaration of pride and welcome to womanhood, guests give gifts, share tales of women's rights.

Hudough Dance (April): A Native American custom described as a 'special dance' for both sexes where women can ask men to dance and couples may lie together without threatening family continuity. (Described as a custom, not a a spell for user to perform directly.)

Blessing on Your Genitals (April): During full moon, meditation to temple, invoking Aphrodite, asking her to bless genitals for health and pleasure, burning musk incense, offering cunt-shaped cookies, conches, jewels, a mirror.

Blessing on Lovers (April): Under full moon, gathering friends, offering wine/juices and seafood, best friend speaks to Goddess of Love, couple exchanges myrtle branches (or orange blossoms, jasmine, cherry blossoms), couple makes vows, exchanging rings, feeding each other, jumping over a broom/branch for beginnings.

Devotion for the Dead (April): Visiting loved one's grave (or creating memorial table), lighting a week-long white candle anointed with sandalwood oil, burning frankincense/myrrh, chatting informally, closing with blessing.

Haloa (April): Greek women’s festival. Described as a women-only event for free speech, creating pastries shaped like genitals, frank discussions about sexuality, sumptuous banquet, dancing, and purification from troubles. Modern version involves gathering in women’s club, burning incense, decorating tables, honoring sisters, and sharing stories.

Artemis & The Children (May): A story emphasizing Artemis as protector of young life. Practitioner guided to gather youngsters, create a party for them, take them to the zoo, have them tell stories, bless them on the head with strength and sharp minds.

Spell for May: Blessing on the Children (May): During full moon, dressing children for a birthday party, making flower/herbal crowns, baking cake, drawing crescent moon on forehead with blue chalk, chanting 'I mark you with the sign of Artemis, the young crescent moon. Now you have inner protection for the rest of the year.'

Arretophoria: Nymph Festival (May): A modern version for young girls (nymphs) to perform a house blessing. Dressing girl in pretty dress, crown, bell, purifying incense, circling house three times clockwise while chanting for protection, repeating inside, adapting words for car/possessions.

Spell to Find a Home (May): During waxing moon, drawing desired home with Magic Markers, placing drawing under a brown candle on altar, taking earth from desired vicinity, lighting white candles, chanting 'This is my home, my earth, my cave, my castle. Mother Demeter, bring me to my shelter. Mother Demeter, bring me home! Bring me home!', repeating three nights, casting biodegradable remnants into living water.

Spell for Productive Studying (May): Lighting a purple candle for hard work/fame/fortune (or yellow for important but vague goals), burning sage/incense, meditating on goal, chanting 'Goddess of Wisdom, to you I pray. My mind clear and receptive stay; All in true accord with thee, As my word, so mote it be. Give me light! Blessed be.'

Spell to Find a (Nonspecific) Job (May): During waxing moon, using divination to assess talents, buying a yellow candle inscribed with name three times, writing wish list (with desired income) on white paper, visualizing employment, burning incense, repeating seven nights, leaving ashes in flower pots of target offices.

Chanting for Personal Power (June): Under full moon, finding a private place, offerings of apples/pears/incense to Juno, meditating on her, chanting 'Juno, Hera, Queen of the Powers, Bring me, bring out my own, my own. Let all that is needed be done well, be done well. Let me sing of your glory under the moon. I am ready for my personal power. I am the arm that does your work. I am the mind of your thoughts. I am the will of your achievements. I am the conductor of your power. Hera, Juno, Hebe, Theria, I am the heart of your love.'

Spell to Magically Defeat a Law (June): During waxing moon, soaking a copy of unjust law in vinegar overnight, assembling paper links related to the law/supporters, creating a magic circle, invoking Dark Mother of Erebus and Furies (Tisiphone, Alecto, Megaera), giving account of injustice, snipping paper links, burning them in a cauldron with own hair and brandy, dancing counterclockwise, feasting with places set for Furies, thanking spirits, continuing activism.

Spell to Stop Harassment at Home, Work, or School (June): During waning moon, preparing altar with white candles, using a black candle to represent harasser, anointing it with urine, writing harasser’s name (or 'whoever is oppressing me') three times, rolling in black pepper, burning candle for three nights, chanting ' [Name] or [whoever is harassing me] will stop. In Aradia's name be this done. By his own mistakes, by his own fault, he will bring himself down, down, down! According to my word, so mote it be.', throwing drippings in harasser's path or living water.

Voodoo Spell for Wealth (July): During full moon for three days, making a green cloth doll representing self, stuffing with bay leaves/clover, tying own hair to head, giving eyes/nose/mouth, making a scarf from own clothing, writing desired money/wealth on white paper with red ink, pinning to doll, placing on white altar cloth, anointing with cinnamon oil, sprinkling with gold dust, tying green cord around doll’s middle three times while chanting 'Thus do I bind you, thus do I tie you to wealth! You shall know no rest until you have captured the desired and the best!', visualizing abundance, then hiding doll until results manifest, burning it in herbal fire.

Self-Blessing for Health, Wealth, Love, or Wisdom (July): Using powdered mountain ash leaves, walking into nature, establishing directions, blowing powder towards east/south/west/north with left hand to right palm while chanting offerings to guardians for specific blessings and protection, returning to east, concluding 'The magic circle I have turned. Powder of the sacred ash I have offered. Now, Diana, send my wishes true to me.'
The Magic of Mugwort (Artemisia absinthium) (July): Adding mugwort to dinner for a friend or lover to increase amorousness or virility.

Prayers for Peace in the Family (July): During new moon, fasting, giving food to girls, sleeping with henna tied to palms, baking wheat flour shells filled with butter-soaked cotton, setting them on fire while praying for peace in homes, passing tray of lights, floating lights on river as offerings.

A Marriage Ceremony for Those Who Feel It Is Time for Trysting (July): For natural people, gay or straight. Buying two chalices, two flower crowns, preparing a tray of food representing Tree of Life (roots, stems, flowers, seeds, fruits), gathering friends, invoking Juno/Hera, partners extending hands over tray, reciting vows, feeding each other, jumping over a broom/branch of myrtle/oak/rowan/willow.

Spell to Increase Your Business (August): Monthly during full moon, burning Echinacea, augustifolia, cubeb berries, and yellow dock mixed with sandalwood powder on charcoal each morning and night, chanting 'Augusta, Increaser, make my business grow as you grow your best corn! I am doing business in the universe, and I am willing and ready to receive your wealth.'
Spell for Health & Against Accidents (August): Drinking feverfew tea warm once a week, or carrying feverfew in a red flannel bag for protection.

Spell to See Visions (August): Burning sandalwood incense, anise seeds, myrtle, and Indian hemp (legal variety) mixed with frankincense/myrrh before meditating or retiring to bed, asking for blessings from unusual beings/animals in dreams.
Spell to End Hatred Between Two People (August): Soaking ironweed in whiskey for seven days, straining, giving the doctored brew to the two people at odds in tea/coffee/drinks.

Spell Thanking the Goddess for Favors Received (September): Burning acacia flowers/sap (gum arabic) incense on charcoal in morning and night, sending prayers of thanks or for good luck/health/needs, chanting 'Diana, lovely goddess who runs in front of the winds, You who grant the wishes of your children And tend to their needs like a mother, Thank you for the blessings you have bestowed upon me, And thank you for the blessings yet to come.'

Spell to Drive a Poltergeist from Your Premises (September): Boiling bistort in water, straining, adding to floor wash, sprinkling on carpets, saying 'Out, out, out, restless spirits go, only the good can stay, the rest of you must be gone!'

Spell to Help Angry Couples to Kiss & Make Up (September): Placing black cohosh around the bed where couple sleeps, chanting 'Angry soul and painful heart change into white doves and fly!' three times, visualizing couple smiling.

Spell to Keep a Wandering Lover at Home (September): Brewing yerba mate tea with pure honey, having target drink it (can be hidden in wine/coffee), whispering 'Warm seed, warm heart [name] and [your name] never part.' three times over it.

Skira: Creativity Festival (September): Gathering art supplies (clay, paints, glitter, gypsum) on a specific day, creating goddess images from soul, parading works through streets, displaying beautiful pieces on altar with flowers, holding Skira parties.

To Destroy an Enemy's Power to Harm (October): Burning ague root, crushed patchouli leaves, myrrh, olibanum tears, wood betony incense on charcoal, saying enemy’s name three times, chanting 'Burn fire, rise smoke, Hecate's attention now I draw! Let the evil sent to me be returned to its house. Burn fire, rise smoke!' seven nights before sleep.

Spell to Stop Slander & Gossip (October): Powdered cloves, writing slanderer’s name backward nine times with red ink on white paper (or 'whoever is slandering me'), burning cloves in morning/night for seven days, burning paper with cloves on last night, casting ashes into living water.
Spell to Travel in Safety (October): Sprinkling Iceland moss on bottom of suitcase/luggage, covering with thin paper, putting clothes on top, trusting Mother Nature's protection.

Rite to Honor the Dead (October): Creating an altar for ancestors with white cloth, flowers, water, pictures of departed relatives, white/yellow devotional candles, incense, red fruit/hard candies, speaking to ancestors, then visiting graves (if applicable) on Halloween/November 1.

Spell to Let Go (October): Creating a list of things to let go (resentments, anger, psychic garbage), creating altar with black cloth and fallen leaves, lighting two black candles, burning dispelling incense (sandalwood, frankincense, myrrh, cedar), praying to Goddess to recycle/bury/compost burdens, then burning list in flames and casting remnants into living water.

Spell to Improve Psychic Powers (November): During new or full moon, dress in yellow, place yellow candles on altar with crystal ball in center, drink saffron tea, meditate, visualize spine as serpent uncoiling, burn psychic herbs (wood betony, sandalwood, olibanum, uva ursi, nutmeg, orrisroot), chant 'I am the channel of divine insight in the universe. My inner eyes see what my god sees. My inner ears hear what my god hears. My inner heart loves what my god loves.', holding fleeting feelings before sleep, burning yellow candles, fresh flowers.

Stenia: The Bitching Festival (November): A modern version for women to discuss negative emotions. Anciently, matrons would be visited by young women in tents, exchanging verbal insults, throwing dirt bombs, wrestling matches (short of drawing blood), resolving resentments. Acknowledging therapy groups as modern equivalent.

Spell to Help Those in Depression (December): During waxing moon, standing in a 7-9 foot circle, lighting high-quality temple incense (frankincense/myrrh or sage), holding hands up, inhaling deeply, chanting invocation to Hecate (Transformer and Midwife) by sage/herb to lift spirit, repeating three consecutive nights.
Spell to Find Inner Peace (December): Sending Winter Solstice greeting cards to those with whom one has quarreled, rubbing lavender buds on card/including in envelope for credibility.
Winter Solstice Practices (December): Decorating a Yule Tree with round balls/lights, drinking eggnog, burning candles, writing in journal for reflection, contemplating the soul.
Spell to Bring Fast Luck (December): Placing seven job's tears seeds in pillow and sleeping on them every night.
Spell to Attract a Lover (December): Carrying queen's root (Stillingia sylvatica) in a small red bag on person. (Drinking queen's root tea for conception is also mentioned).

Spell to Call on the Angelic Forces (December): During evening star rise, lighting a white candle or seven-power candle, burning specific herbs (pipsissewa, rose powder, violet powder, vanilla) mixed, talking to angels about heart matters/survival/miracles/writing a book, repeating seven days, transferring light from one candle to next without putting out.

relevant_quotes.text: The first thing we must put into that emptiness is boundless courage. We must have the courage to renew our faith in ourselves as children of the natural gods; we ourselves are like our parents, godlike.

Anna—the oldest of gods, the Grandmother of Time, the young thing of the springtime, shape shifter, the old hag of the wintertime—is our captain on this annual magical journey around the brilliant sun.

I am the kind of god who likes to work with those who are aware, not the sluggish. I recommend to you a more cheerful path, not the old half-conscious one, where eyes are cast downward and your soul drags behind you as if in permanent rejection of the gifts I packed into your genes! See! No space suit needed, the spaceship Earth is already in gear. I set my course carefully as we spin 200 miles per second in space. The new year is my latest creation—enjoy yourself in my honor.
'The women who will develop spirituality for themselves will be stronger for it. They will not bum out. They will stop and smell the roses on their way to liberation.'

What is the lesson of this hex? That it is in the interest of women and men to help clean up their communities and protect them from killers. That it is in the domain of the Goddess to respond and help women to make their lives safe. That women have the psychic power to petition their own universal powerful force in their own behalf.
The Goddess is alive! Magic is afoot!' And each time the group chants back, 'Magic is afoot!'

critical_analysis.relevance: This book holds significant relevance within Western Esotericism and Occultism as a foundational text in Dianic Wicca and the broader Feminist Spirituality Movement. Budapest's work provides a practical and experiential framework for practitioners to engage with goddess-centered traditions, explicitly offering an alternative, and often confrontational, stance against patriarchal religious and societal structures. Its emphasis on self-empowerment, communal ritual, and the integration of magic for both personal well-being and social justice (e.g., hexing for protection, political activism) distinguishes it within occult literature. By detailing monthly 'Goddess Speaks' messages, specific aspects, and numerous spells, the book serves as a technical manual for aligning one's life with natural and lunar cycles, making it a valuable resource for those seeking operative magic rooted in the divine feminine. Its contextualization of ancient practices, including those from diverse cultures, highlights a global perspective on goddess worship, while its personal stories ground the magical theory in lived experience.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of women interested in feminist spirituality, Dianic Wicca, goddess worship, and practical magic, particularly those seeking empowerment and liberation from patriarchal norms. It also appeals to individuals who wish to explore ancient European pagan traditions, integrate spiritual practices into daily life, and engage in self-healing, protection, and manifestation. The book’s accessible language, clear spell instructions, and emphasis on community-based rituals make it suitable for both beginners and experienced practitioners within occultism and esotericism, especially those who value an intersectional feminist and ecologically conscious approach to magic. The narrative style, incorporating personal anecdotes and historical insights, makes the complex subject matter engaging and relatable for a broad audience open to alternative spiritual paths.
